Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Star Formation History of the Universe Using ZEUS-2
Award.AbstractNarration: Star formation activity in the universe peaked 2 to 6 billion years after the Big Bang, corresponding to redshifts between 1 and 3. Most of the radiant energy from these stars was absorbed by dust in their nascent molecular clouds, re-radiated in the far infrared part of the spectrum, and can be observed today redshifted to the submillimeter. To measure the intrinsic luminosities and star formation rates of these galaxies, one must therefore observe in the submillimeter bands. Moreover, the star forming interstellar medium (ISM) is cooled by atomic spectral line radiation observable at these wavelengths; hence submillimeter spectroscopy is critical for understanding the star formation process. This project makes use of the scientific capabilities of the ZEUS and ZEUS-2 spectrographs, developed with prior funding from the Advanced Technologies & Instrumentation (ATI) and Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) programs, to observe specific atomic fine-structure lines of carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen in high-redshift galaxies. ZEUS-2 will be used on the Caltech Submillimeter Observatory (CSO) and the Atacama Pathfinder Experiment (APEX), together with other space- and ground-based follow-up observations in the millimeter, submillimeter, and far infrared in order to: (1) extend an ongoing survey of [CII] emission lines to deeper redshift and lower luminosity, tracing the change is star formation mode over time; (2) observe [OI] and [NII] lines in the same redshift range, to trace the changes in stellar populations; (3) observe gravitationally lensed galaxies comparable to the Milky Way in luminosity at redshifts around 2; and (4) study the connection between starbursts and active galactic nuclei. These observations will represent a key stepping stone linking discovery with the Herschel Space Telescope to future spatially resolved investigations with the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA). ZEUS-2 also lays the ground-work for instrument development and science opportunities that will be enabled by a future spectrometer on the proposed 25-meter Cerro Chajnantor Atacama Telescope (CCAT). The project will support the active involvement of multiple graduate and undergraduate students, many from under-represented groups, in instrument development and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Our goal is to trace the history of star formation and galaxy assembly over cosmic time with particular emphasis on the redshift (z) 5 to 1 epoch which corresponds to about 1.2 to 6 billion years after the Big Bang.  This was the epoch of peak star formation activity in the Universe during which most of the stars that exist today formed.  We investigate star formation using the far-infrared lines of singly ionized carbon (C+), singly ionized nitrogen (N+), and doubly ionized oxygen (O++).  These lines cool the gas that is heated by nearby massive stars. They therefore trace both the physical conditions of this gas (its temperature, density and mass) and the surface temperatures and spatial distributions of the stars.

Previous NSF awards funded the graduate and undergraduate students who designed and built our ZEUS and ZEUS-2 spectrometers.  These spectrometers are used on the world’s premier single dish submillimeter telescopes to detect the far-infrared lines from young galaxies in the early Universe (Fig. 1 & 2). We obtained a few observational firsts that launched new areas of science involving star formation on galactic scales, but our most significant discovery to date arose from our first redshift 1 to 2 C+ line surveys of ~2 dozen galaxies. The C+ line traces the spatial extent of star formation, and the high C+ line luminosity we found indicated intense star formation extending over multiple kilo-parsec sized gas disks (Fig. 3).  Essentially the whole galaxy must be enveloped in star formation at rates of approaching 1000 times that of the Milky Way, or ~1000 stars/year!  We speculate that these enormous star forming disks are created and nourished by gas that is infalling from the Cosmic Web. The Cosmic Web traces large scale structures and contains much of the gas reservoir of the Universe.  This high rate of star formation is sustained by this infalling gas enabling creation of the giant elliptical galaxies seen at the centers of galaxy clusters in the present-day Universe.  The discovery of this “quiescent accretion mode” of galaxy growth was a surprise. In the local Universe, massive galaxies appear to be made predominantly through mergers of galaxies. To check our theories, we have begun a program to trace this infalling gas along the Cosmic Web through its C+ and N+ line radiation with our ZEUS-2 spectrometer. To discover the infalling gas is to confirm the major mode of star formation during the epoch when most of the stars of today’s Universe formed.

We followed up and confirmed our C+ discoveries with spatially resolved C+ observations obtained with the ALMA array.  Meanwhile we are absorbed in a survey of galaxies at earlier times (redshift 2.5 to 4.6) in their O++ and N+ line emission. This line ratio is sensitive to the surface temperature of the stars that ionize the gas.  More massive stars have higher surface temperatures, and much shorter main sequence lifetimes than less massive stars.  Therefore, the O++/N+ line ratio reveals the most massive star on the main sequence and the time since the last major star formation event.  Our first survey encompasses fifteen galaxies in the O++ line and four in N+ (Fig. 4).  Within this small survey, we find that most of these luminous galaxies formed stars about 8 to 10 million years ago, but at least one in our sample formed stars just 2.5 million years ago.  Indeed, our 3C368 results suggests that cyclic star formation with periods of ~6 million years may be common. Summarizing, our C+/N+/O++ studies of star forming galaxies explores the processes through which galaxies build up their gas components, convert it into stars which evolve and die as supernovae, and finally replenish the intergalactic medium in heavy elements through supernovae driven outflows. This program, together with our future infall studies therefore traces the critical steps of galaxy formation and evolution across the epoch of peak star formation in the Universe.

Broader Impacts.  Nearly all our research includes strong graduate and undergraduate student participation.  Over the past 20 years, 67 different undergraduates (31 females, 4 minority) and two high school students worked with us, mostly supported by NSF grants.  About 1/4 later attended graduate school in the sciences.  Eight graduate students worked on ZEUS/ZEUS-2 and three PhDs (two more are in process) were produced based largely on these systems.  The instrument work and observing runs provide a unique hands on experience critical to the development of the next generation of instrument-savvy scientists.  ZEUS-2 was the first to use superconducting TES arrays for astrophysical spectroscopy (Fig. 5). Our instrumentation efforts are leveraged through interactions with national facilities like NASA GSFC and NIST Boulder, and many high technology parts of the instruments are made in local machine and electronic shops.  Our science is publicized through our teaching and outreach efforts.
